body:
I can reproduce the 1-2min runtime with this code:

```python
import numpy as np
from sktime.transformations.panel.rocket import MiniRocket
train = np.random.rand(100, 2000).astype("float32")

t = MiniRocket()
t.fit(train)
t.transform(train)
```

Perhaps it has to do with the default parameter choice?
```python
        num_kernels=10_000,
        max_dilations_per_kernel=32,
```
Yes, the author's code take 0.5 second for this function. I checked the default in his code, seems same to me.

how odd. Well, I suppose someone needs to take it upon them to profile the runs.
Sounds like a good first issue, at least the "profile and report" part.

Perhaps related to this?
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3103

We had to remove some estimators from the tests since they were leading to segfaults.

`MiniRocket` is on the list, but there were more estimators. Any ideas what they have in common, @haskarb?
From the list, it mostly looks like numba part is common. I'm not quite sure, if another reason could be the _fit and _transform function?

The issue is the format of `train = np.random.rand(100, 2000).astype("float32")` in combination with `_vectorize()`.

Rocket is expecting an array of shape `(100, 1, 2000)`, yet if gets an array of shape `(100, 2000)`. This triggers _vectorize(), which truns it into 2000 calls of an array of shape `(1,100)`? E.g. the vectorize functionality seems bogus. @fkiraly:  Not sure, why it is triggered in `fit()` anyways to split the data? This is never correct.

A fast fix for the above code is: 

```python
import numpy as np
from sktime.transformations.panel.rocket import MiniRocket
train = np.random.rand(100, 2000).astype("float32")
train = train.reshape(100, 1, 2000)

t = MiniRocket()
t.fit(train)
t.transform(train)

```
E.g. reshape the array.

Now timings are within seconds:

fit done in: 0.17706 s
pred done in: 2.01951 s


Anyhow, the `_vectorize()`- method should be fixed.

> E.g. the vectorize functionality seems bogus

It is currently not actual vectorization but a loop implementing numpy stype broadcasting rules.

I was hoping initially that it could be easily turned into "proper" vectorization later, but it is a can of worms. Too late to rename the class...

FYI, `numpy.vectorize` uses the same terminology and is also not vectorization in the strict sense, but broadcasting:
https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.vectorize.html

This is what the current implementation generalizes.

Regarding the above: 2D numpy arrays of shape (n, m), when passed to transformers, are interpreted as *one* (1) time series with n time stamps and m variables. So you are asking the transformer to compute transforms of 2000 univariate time series.

This is because all transformers apply to single time series and panels of time series. For interface consistency, numpy2D can only be interpreted as on of the two possible things, a single time series with n time stamps, m variables, or n univariate time series with m time stamps.

Previously, we had a situation where some people were saying, "*my* transformers interpret numpy2D like this", and other people were saying, "*my* transformers interpret numpy2D like that" (historically what led to the distinction between `series` and `panel` submodule) but it is uniform since about a year, I think.

with the above explanation, I would see there being neither an issue with `_vectorize` nor with `MiniRocket`. Please reopen and comment if you disagree.

We may have to explain better the data type conventions for transformers, but that's part of the current effort on writing a transformers/pipelines tutorial anyway.

Sorry, have to reopen, due to two issues:

- MiniRocket has the tag `"univariate-only": True`. This is violated by implicit broadcasting. Shouldn't it rather throw an exception?

- As I understand it, each call to fit overwrites the state of the previous call to fit. Thus, every call to transform uses the state of the last fit. This is also not the expected/intended behavior.

> MiniRocket has the tag `"univariate-only": True`. This is violated by implicit broadcasting. Shouldn't it rather throw an exception?

No, that's correct. Univariate estimators are always broadcast/vectorized, this tag tells whether that is the case, vs genuine multivariate estimators.

Either way, even if we wanted to change that it would be a change to the base class and not to `MiniRocket`.

> As I understand it, each call to fit overwrites the state of the previous call to fit. Thus, every call to transform uses the state of the last fit. This is also not the expected/intended behavior.

It is the expected and intended behaviour.
`fit` always resets the estimator, this is a universal interface convention of `sktime` and also one of `sklearn`.

Again, it would be a proposed change to central interfaces of the base class, nothing to do with `MiniRocket`.
let me know if you think it's fine to close, given the explanation.
@MatthewMiddlehurst @TonyBagnall may I ask for your opinion? Do you think that broadcasting the fit operation is a good choice? Given that the state is not stored and overwritten.

@patrickzib I need to have a closer look at Transformations because I dont fully understand what has happened to transformers this last year. I do know that you should no longer pass data to the transformer in (n_case, series_length) format, because transformers no longer handle (n_case, series_length) in a way compatible with scikit learn type representation. 

I think this 
import numpy as np
from sktime.transformations.panel.rocket import MiniRocket
train = np.random.rand(100, 2000).astype("float32")
t = MiniRocket()
t.fit(train)
t.transform(train)

is now simply incorrect usage, and if it is used as such will create logical or runtime errors that will be very hard to detect and create incorrect results. There is no longer a distinction between "panel" and "series" data, and (n_case, series_length) is not treated as modelling multiple instances. This is a bug in my opinion. I think the classification transformer should throw an error if passed 2d numpy. I would have preferred to have kept the distinction of different behaviour, but it is all so deeply embedded in datatypes etc this seems the most practical solution to me, at least short term. Use of 2D numpy in classification was in fact introduced a year or so into the project. I pushed for it simply for scikit compatibility. One option would be just to remove the option. Another would be to subtype the two types of transformer again. Neither is trivial, and for now I think an error is the best way for all panel transformers.
